name: White Eared Pheasant
description: It belongs to the group of so-called eared pheasants, characterized by elongated feathers on the sides of the head. It forms several subspecies, with males and females barely differing in appearance.
spread_note: Southern Asia – from Tibet and northern India to southern and central China
food_note: Seeds, shoots, and other plant parts, invertebrates
image_alt: White eared pheasant, photo: Tereza Mrhálková, Prague Zoo
proportions: Body length 86–96 cm; tail length 46–58 cm; weight of males 2.3–2.75 kg, females 1.4–2 kg
reproduction: Females lay 4–9 eggs, incubating them for 24 days – data from captivity.
attractions: With its strong beak, it literally digs up the soil to find food. It spends most of the year in groups of up to thirty birds, pairing off during breeding season. Highly resilient, it commonly inhabits snowy slopes. It can glide low over snow efficiently to reach food sources, using its broad tail during gliding flight.
breeding: The first white eared pheasant arrived in Prague from the ‘Durrell’ Zoo on Jersey in 1977, living at the zoo until 1992 before moving to Ostrava. Meanwhile, other individuals arrived, including a pair in 1990 that raised the first chicks in 1992. It spends winters in the zoo’s backstage area, away from visitor spaces.
